Deficiency of B vitamins, including B2, B6, B12, and niacin
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia + immune thrombocytopenia)
Infectious mononucleosis due to Epstein-Barr virus

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by symptoms like arthropathy, alopecia, and in some cases, central nervous system involvement leading to cognitive dysfunction such as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune rheumatic disease that leads to the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. Patients may experience atrophic scarring and arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can cause synovitis and, in severe cases, result in deformities and physical disabilities.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune condition that causes widespread inflammation and tissue damage in affected organs. It can lead to symptoms such as arthropathy, alopecia, and skin changes including atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It can also lead to symptoms like alopecia and atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including arthropathy, alopecia, and in later stages, neurological disorders including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. It can cause painful joint inflammation (synovitis) as well as skin and nail changes.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to numerous signs and symptoms that may include arthritic pain, skin changes, and potentially neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In skin, it can lead to lesions that might mimic atrophic scarring. Arthropathy can also occur in sarcoidosis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause changes in the skin, including atrophic scarring, and may also affect joints leading to arthropathy. Some forms can induce neurological symptoms such as delirium.

diagnoses: Infectious Diseases (e.g., Viral or Bacterial Infections)
Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) with systemic involvement
Lupus Nephritis as part of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
Rheumatic Diseases (e.g., Mixed Connective Tissue Disease)

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark symptom, and diabetes can also affect multiple body systems leading to a wide range of complications such as skin and ear infections (potentially contributing to Otitis externa), potentially related to dry eyes through diabetic retinopathy or keratoconjunctivitis sicca.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth; can also cause lymphadenopathy due to chronic immune stimulation and might lead to skin conditions that could indirectly contribute to otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause lymphadenopathy and weaken the immune system, making individuals more susceptible to infections including Otitis externa; might result in hyperglycemia as a part of metabolic syndrome associated with chronic infection or antiretroviral therapy.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: An inflammatory disease that can cause lymphadenopathy and affect almost any organ in the body, including the eyes (potentially leading to dry eyes), lungs (causing cough), and less commonly affect glucose metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs (causing cough) but can also cause lymphadenopathy and affect other parts of the body, including the eye (potentially contributing to dry eyes), and indirectly affect glucose metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Cancer of the lymphatic system can cause lymphadenopathy; depending on the type and location, it may also affect the patient's general condition, potentially influencing glucose metabolism and leading to symptoms like cough or dry eyes due to general illness effects.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that can cause dry eyes (as part of Sjögren's syndrome), lymphadenopathy, and could potentially lead to kidney disease which might result in hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.reasoning: While it's a less common association, allergic conditions could potentially lead to dry eyes, cough due to post-nasal drip, and in severe cases, secondary infections that could manifest as otitis externa. However, the link to hyperglycemia and lymphadenopathy would be indirect, if present.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.reasoning: A viral infection that can cause cough, lymphadenopathy, and complications that could potentially relate to otitis externa. Less directly associated with dry eyes and hyperglycemia but could be considered in a differential diagnosis especially in unvaccinated individuals.

diagnoses.name: Rosacea
diagnoses.reasoning: Primarily affects the skin causing rash and can also lead to ocular rosacea (dry eyes). While not directly related to cough, hyperglycemia, or lymphadenopathy, in complex cases with multiple underlying conditions, it could be a concurrent diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disease can lead to widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, including the kidneys, leading to chronic kidney disease. It can also cause oral ulcers and increase certain immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Another autoimmune disorder, which primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands. Chronic kidney disease can result from the involvement of the kidneys, and one of the hallmark symptoms is dryness that can lead to ulcers. It's also associated with higher levels of certain immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune condition that can cause a variety of systemic symptoms, including increased immunoglobulin levels indicative of chronic inflammation. It can lead to secondary Sjögren's Syndrome, which might explain ulcers and chronic kidney disease. While it primarily affects joints, it can sometimes lead to hypermobility in the early stages due to joint damage.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This condition shares characteristics with several diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Symptoms can include high levels of immunoglobulins, joint hypermobility, and renal involvement leading to chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reason: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. It's known for causing mouth and genital ulcers, and may also lead to systemic issues including increased immunoglobulin levels and kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reason: HIV infection can lead to increased levels of certain immunoglobulins as the immune system responds to the virus. Chronic kidney disease is a common complication in untreated or advanced HIV/AIDS. Ulcers and irritability/neurological symptoms can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis B or C
diagnoses.reason: Chronic hepatitis infection can lead to increased immunoglobulin levels due to the ongoing immune response against the virus. These infections can cause extrahepatic manifestations such as kidney disease and ulcers.

diagnoses.name: IgG4-related Disease
diagnoses.reason: A fibro-inflammatory condition that can affect multiple organs, including the kidneys, leading to chronic kidney disease. It's characterized by elevated levels of IgG4, a subtype of immunoglobulin.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.reason: This rare, inherited immune system disorder affects phagocytes, leading to frequent infections, which can drive up immunoglobulin levels and potentially affect the kidneys, causing chronic disease.

diagnoses.name: Sharpe Syndrome (Mixed Connective Tissue Disease)
diagnoses.reason: Included as a distinct diagnosis due to its unique combination of features from different rheumatic diseases, which can include high immunoglobulin levels, kidney involvement, and possibly hypermobility and ulcers as noted in broader connective tissue disorder symptoms.

diagnoses: Gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., Celiac disease, Crohn's disease)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Anemia (various types, e.g., iron deficiency anemia)
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes, dry mouth, difficulty focusing vision due to the dry eyes, and it can go along with sinus problems like sinutitis. Increased immunoglobulins are often seen due to the immune response.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause dry eyes and sinutitis due to inflammation. Patients may have difficulty focusing vision because of the eye dryness. Elevated immunoglobulin levels can be a marker of the disease activity.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs and tissues. Symptoms can include dry eyes, sinusitis, and visual difficulties. Hyperactivity in the immune system leads to increased levels of immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Hyper IgG4 Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that leads to inflammation in various parts of the body, including the sinuses and glands leading to dry eyes. It is characterized by increased levels of IgG4, a type of immunoglobulin.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels that can lead to vision problems, including difficulty focusing. While not directly linked to sinutitis or dry eyes, systemic inflammation could contribute to such symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease causing vasculitis in various organs, potentially leading to sinutitis, and can have ophthalmologic manifestations including dry eyes and vision problems. Elevated immunoglobulins can be associated with the disease.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, which can be accompanied by symptoms such as dry eyes, sinutitis, and cognitive impairments like difficulty focusing vision. The connection to increased immunoglobulins and hyperactivity is less direct but can be associated with the immune dysfunction in some patients.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause visual problems due to optic neuritis, and while less common, symptoms like dry eyes and sinutitis can appear. Increased immunoglobulin levels in cerebrospinal fluid are a diagnostic marker.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. Eye problems, including difficulty focusing vision, are common. While sinutitis isn't a primary symptom, systemic inflammation could play a role. Increased immunoglobulins may occur.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease affecting multiple organs, particularly the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include dry eyes and visual disturbances. While not directly associated with sinutitis, involvement of the sinus is possible. Hyperactivity of the immune system is evidenced by increased immunoglobulins.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with secondary hypertension
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with secondary rhinorrhea
Common Cold or Viral Upper Respiratory Tract Infection
Asthma with gastrointestinal symptoms (rare, consider in differential diagnosis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include sudden dysarthria (difficulty speaking), headache, and paresthesia (abnormal sensation).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like dysarthria, dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), paresthesia, and potentially scintillation (flashes of light).

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura) such as scintillation before the onset of headache. Other symptoms can include paresthesia and dysarthria.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms depending on its location, including headache, dysarthria, paresthesia, and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces stroke-like symptoms — including dysarthria, paresthesia, and headache — but typically lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A neurological disease that affects nerve cells responsible for controlling voluntary muscle movement, leading to symptoms such as dysarthria and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which can lead to difficulty talking (dysarthria) and swallowing (dysphagia), among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to symptoms such as paresthesia, dysarthria, and potentially difficulty swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Primary CNS Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that occurs in the lymph tissue of the brain and spinal cord, presenting symptoms such as headache, dysarthria, dysphagia, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a diseased blood vessel within the brain bursts, allowing blood to leak inside the brain. Symptoms can include sudden headache, dysarthria, and paresthesia.

diagnoses: Hepatitis C related Chronic Liver Disease
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Viral infections (such as HIV or severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 [SARS-CoV-2])
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with thrombocytopenia)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Lupus with Central Nervous System Involvement
Chronic Kidney Disease (related to lupus nephritis)
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Parvovirus B19, Hepatitis C)
